appeals.sector: Country cluster for South Sudan, Tanzania and Uganda

results.name: UGA: Epidemic - 01-2025 - Ebola Virus Outbreak
results.summary:
On 30 January 2025, the Ministry of Health declared an outbreak of Sudan Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) in Kampala District. This declaration followed confirmation from three national laboratories: the Central Public Health Laboratories, the Uganda Virus Research Institute, and Makerere University Laboratories.


The index case was a 32-year-old male nurse employed at Mulago National Referral Hospital. He initially presented fever-like symptoms and sought treatment from multiple health facilities, including Mulago National Referral Hospital in Kampala, Saidina Abubakar Islamic Hospital in Matunga, Wakiso District, and Mbale Regional Referral Hospital, as well as from a traditional healer.


The patient had a five-day history of high fever, chest pain, and difficulty breathing, which later progressed to unexplained bleeding from multiple body sites. Despite medical intervention, the patient experienced multiple organ failure and subsequently succumbed to the illness at Mulago National Referral Hospital. Following the confirmation of this index case, the Ministry of Health activated the Incident Management Team and dispatched Rapid Response Teams to Mbale City and Saidina Abubakar Islamic Hospital in Matugga to list all of the contacts and isolate them. Since the identification of the index case on 30 January 2025, ongoing investigations and contact tracing have led to a steady increase in the number of contacts, reaching 265 as of 10 February 2025, across the districts of Kampala, Wakiso, Jinja, Mbale, and other areas. Of the listed contacts, 62 per cent are health workers who have been quarantined at the National Isolation Centre in Mulago. As of 10 February 2025, there were nine confirmed cases, including the index case.

field_reports.description:
Context and current situation

Following the DRC situation, new arrivals fled to Uganda and neighboring countries. In Uganda, receiving points such as Nyakabande in Kisoro, Matanda in Kanungu, Bubukwanga in Bundibudgyo continued to experience spillover of new arrivals increasing exponentially to over 200% compared to 2024 population movement trends. The interagency report indicate variation in situations in transit centers and further highlights an expected increase of the influx due to a deteriorating situation in Goma and Itumi.

Kisoro. – Nyakabande transit center

In Kisoro, 2,501 (1,199 male and 1,302 female) individuals comprising of 1,340 households new arrivals were received from 27 February-5 March 2025 compared to 1,866 (968 HH) received in the previous week (16th to 23rd Feb) . This shows an increase of about 25% of the new arrivals this week compared to the previous week. This brings to cumulative figures of 11,481 individuals of 6,175 Households received and registered through level one at the transit centre since January 2025. The total estimated population at the transit centre as of 5 March 2025 was 4,220 individuals of 2,121 HH. Other POCs, upon verification, are transferred to allocated settlements.

Kanungu-  Matanda transit center

In Matanda TC, 642 (344 Male and 298 female) individuals of 374 households of new arrivals were received from 27 February-5 March 2025 compared to 701 (393 HH) received in the previous week. This shows a decrease of about 18% of the new arrivals this week. This brings to cumulative figures of 6,365 individuals of 3,833 Households received and registered through level one at the transit centre since 1 January 2025. The total estimated population at Matanda transit centre as of 26 February 2025 was 2,875 individuals of 1,329 HH. Other POCs, upon verification, are transferred to allocated settlements.

Bundibugyo – Bubukwanga, Kanara and Ntoroko

The total Population at the transit center by 6th March 2025 was at 158HH of 347(179F /51.6%, 168M/48.4%) individuals.  Of the 347, 51.6% (i.e. 179) are Children and 24.5% (85)are male adults  (i.e. 23.9%, 83) are women adults. 

The 24 individuals received by end of 6th March 2025 were walk-ins who reported to have accessed the country through   Mpondwe(10), Bunagana(8), Haibale(5), Kyanika(1) following the seisure of Goma and town by M23. The total Population at the transit center by COB 10th March was at 167HH of 371(190F /51.2%, 181M/48.2%) individuals.  Of the 371, 51.7% (i.e. 192) are Children and 24.3% (.90)are male adults  (23.9%.89) are women adults.

Kikube - Kyangwali

The OPM and UNHCR through the interagency coordination meeting indicated that there was an overwhelming number of new arrivals entering through the boarder entries of Bugoma,Nsonga and Buhuka, statitsics by the time of the meeting were 873 individuals of 391HHs excluding the majority who are recyclers,average 200 individuals per day. 

Despite the collection points getting overwhelmed, the reception center at Kagoma in Kyangwali is equally stressed with numbers of new arrivals. It has been predicted that the trends are likely to increase day by day.

Situation in the receiving settlements

Currently, the OPM and UNHCR gazzeted three settlements to receive new arrivals from the DRC. These include, Nakivale, Kyangwali and Rwamwanja. Apparently, Nakivale that is receiving from Matanada and Nyakabande has been indicated to be full and the UNHCR have already proposed to re-open Oruchinga through formalized schedule has not been communicated yet. In Kyangwali and Nakivale, the OPM is still filling the vacant spaces that are also deemed to be getting filled up.

Humanitarian Impact

Due to daily influx of POCs through transit centers, there is limited access to food, shelter, protection of refugees, education, healthcare, and other essential services.  A number of humanitarian organizations have already either closed or have “Skelton“ presence in all locations i.e. In Kisoro – Nyakabande, Matanda and Bubukwanga including settlements of Nakivale, Kyangwali and Rwamwanja.

field_reports.description:
Following heavy rains that occurred on 27th November 2024 from morning at 10:00AM up to evening 6:00PM across Bulambuli and the neighbouring districts, various disaster events occurred.

Flooding occurred in the sub counties of Simu, Muyembe, Bukhalu, Bunalwere, Nbongo and Buyaga and Bulambuli Town Councils. River Simu bursted its banks affecting several households nearby, cutting off Sironko-Kapchorwa road and Tororo cement truck was witnessed to have overturned as a result of the large volume of water on the road. The bridge also on Simu River connecting Simu sub county and Soti sub county had been swept off as well and Nabongo river along Muyembe- Nakapiripit road was cut off affecting people’s homes. The total estimated of households affected in terms being partially submerged and crop destructed is 751 across the 05 subcounties and the 02 town councils.

The landslides also occurred yesterday 27th November 2024 at between 7pm and 9pm, affecting 8 villages (Masugu, Namacele, Mamolo, Taagalu, Lula, Buzemolili, Lusolo and Nakacene) in Buluganya parish, Buluganya sub-county; Sooti sub-county affecting 2 villages (Bunambale, Nabude); Sisiyi and Bulago sub-counties affecting 1 village; in Bulambuli District.

The total population affected stands at 1,540 persons from the 220 households. 125 households were totally destroyed; So far 15 dead bodies have been retrieved (10 male, 5 female; 7 children (6 male and 1 female), 22 people were injured and were taken to Buluganya H/C III and Muyembe H/C IV and 125 people are missing and unaccounted for. 750 people have been displaced with 534 living with their relatives and neighbours and 216 have been displaced to Masugu Primary school. The search for the missing persons continues by the UPDF, URCS and the community.

It should be noted that data presented above on landslides are recorded only from Buluganya subcounty while the assessment are yet to assess and establish the statistics on losses and damages from the other subcounties later and will be reported in the next situation report.

Sectoral findings

The sectors affected were;

i)            Shelter and Housing

ii)          Roads

iii)         WASH

iv)         Agriculture and livelihoods

Disasters magnitude and pre-existing capacity

Flooding although noted above to have affected many villages and subcounties but the magnitude in terms damages and losses is rated as a medium impact.

The landslide was of extremely high magnitude covering about 4.7 square kilometers, in 8 villages. The high impact was in Masugu, Namacele, Masola,Taagalu.

Emergency Support and Relief

Currently, Bulambuli District Local Government, Uganda Red Cross Society, OPM, UPDF, UPF, CARITAS Tororo, Catholic Relief Services, Oxfam, Emergency Operation Centre-Mbale region, media and the local community are still carrying out search and rescue.

Proposed sectoral immediate intervention

i)            Shelter and housing

ii)          Food

iii)         Medicare

iv)         NFIs

v)          Psychosocial Support

vi)         WASH

vii)        Livelihoods and Agriculture

viii)       Road opening

Challenges

i)            In accessible road network.

ii)          Limited financial and logistical resources to support assessment and rapid response considering the scale and nature of disaster.

General Recommendations (Medium to Long term)

i)            There is need to explore both short and long term interventions regarding the re-occurring landslides in Bulambuli.

ii)          UNRA should as soon as possible repair the roads to allow relief aid and services to be delivered to the affected people.

field_reports.description:
Kasese Municipality flood situation. Following yesterday’s heavy downpour in the late evening, today at 10:00 am, the volume of water from River Nyamwaba drastically increased causing it to burst its banks. The overflowing water has diverted to the Municipality into people’s houses affecting 13 villages in Nyamwamba Division, Kasese Municipality, Kasese District, Western Uganda.
 
Close to 1,000 households have been affected, forcing many to vacate their homes and seek shelter with relatives and neighbors. Household property has been severely impacted, leaving many families homeless and in desperate need of assistance.
 
Tragically, four lives have been lost so far:
  1. One woman ventured outside to record a video, unknowingly standing on weak ground and was swept away by the floodwaters.
  2. Another woman attempting to cross a small bridge while carrying a baby fell into the water. Her body has been retrieved, but sadly, the baby is still missing.
  3. A man was observing the water nearby when the soft ground gave way, causing him to fall into the river and lose his life.
     
Our volunteers have been actively disseminating SOND advisories and the rising water levels via community radios, but the urgent needs remain:
  1. 1. Non-food items support.
    2. Setting up an evacuation site at the Nyakasanga playground for temporary shelter.
Below is a list of the affected villages:
  1. Kitoro Cell
  2. Acholiquaters
  3. Mumbuzi
  4. Base Camp Lower
  5. Kizungu
  6. Nyakasanga West
  7. Kisanga A
  8. Kisanga B
  9. Saluti A
  10. Saluti B
  11. Kamulikwizi
  12. Kikonzo
  13. Kisagazi
We continue to carry out assessments of the situation in collaboration with the District Disaster Management Committee. However, some areas remain submerged making them inaccessible for the time being. Despite these challenges, we are working to reach and assist all affected communities as quickly as possible.
 
Reported by:
 
Roland Atwine
Emergency Preparedness and Response (EPR) Assistant
ECHO-PPP Project
 
And
 
Ronald Kanyerezi
Branch Manager
Uganda Red Cross Society
Kasese Branch
 
Date: Saturday, 07th September 2024
Time: 4:08pm
field_reports.summary: UGA: Flood - 09-2024 - Uganda Floods (SOND) Western Region - Kasese District September 2024

field_reports.description:
MASS CASUALTY EVENT DECLARED.📌📌📌

TYPE: MASSIVE GARBAGE LAND SLIDE 

EXACT LOCATION: KITEEZI SOLID WASTE DUMPING SITE- KAMPALA

TYPE OF INCIDENT and SITUATION: Heap of solid waste and land slid over the surrounding residences with entrapment of individuals (Unknown number of individuals trapped in their houses).
More than 50 households trapped underneath the rubble with about 5 people per household, only 10 households have been excavated with 09 confirmed fatalities by the time of the report.

HAZARD: Crowd and incoming traffic, impending rains and unstable garbage heap

ACCESS:  Kiteezi Kabaga road - Off Grace Primary School..

NUMBER AND TYPE OF CASUALTIES: 09 code black have been excavated from the rubble at this point from the South end of the site- pending confirmation from the North end.
No casualties identified yet at the moment. 03 bystanders managed at the scene. More injuries anticipated among rescuers and bystanders 

EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES: Uganda Police (02ambulances), KCCA (03), Tweyambe (01), Red Cross(02), EMS MoH (02).
2 excavators available on site (1 Police, 1 KCCA), three others enroute to the site.
  
Time of Report: 10th August 2024: 1600 hrs

field_reports.description:
Cause:

Rising water from river Semuliki - Increasing raining in Bundibugyo and on the mountain slopes bordering DRC

Population at risk:

20,000 (Estimated)

Date of significant effect reported:

Tuesday 06/08/2024

Current situation

Following the assessment carried out in the period Monday 05/08/2024 – Tuesday 06/08/2024 indicates that a total of 300 households of 1,500 people are heavily affected and hit by floods.

The sub counties that are most heavily hit by floods are Butungama and Rwebisengo.

This estimated affected population of over 1,500 persons are desperate because, they are facing a problem of food insecurity, lack clean water for drinking and animals have no pasture to feed on since all have been submerged in water.

Lack of safe water for domestic use which exposes the public into using contaminated water hence resulting into outbreak of water-borne diseases.

field_reports.description:
The deteriorating security situation in Sudan resulting from the ongoing civil war between the two rival factions of the military government of Sudan, the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) and the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF) is anticipated to push more Sudanese refugees into Uganda. 

The GOvernment of Uganda opened up Kirayndono refugee settlement loctd in Mid-Western region of Uganda to be the resettlement site to the newly arriving refugees and asylum seeker from Sudan.

According to Office of the Prime Minister (OPM) and the UN Refugee Agency (UNHCR) field offices in Kiryandongo where the new arrivals are being resettled, the number of new arrivals per day is 200 asylum seekers who come on their own, in addition to another 160 individuals who are oficially relocated during a weekly convoy from the South Sudan border of Nimule through Nyumanzi reception centre in Adjumani district. This weekly bus covoy is however being hampered by the current closure of Karuma bridge that is currently under repair and thus    

By end of May 2024, UNHCR refugee respoonse dashboard data shows a total of 106,996 individuals (23,116 households) composed of both the old and new caseloads so far resettled in Kiryandongo refugee settlement, out of whom 8,600 individuals are new arrivals from the recently escalated Sudanase conflict; while other 300 indivuduals who just arrived from Sudan are currently being processed at the reception centre. The number of new arrivals is expected to peak to around 61,824 individuals at any point in the year.

Morover, the capacity of Uganda's operation to provide dignified reception to the refugees without any additional, extraordinary support is already exceeded as the situation is being excercebated by the drastic decline in funding for the refugee response. 

the Uganda Red Cross Society condited a needs assessment in kiryandongo refugee settlement between 10th and 17th june 2024 ad established critical humanitarian gaps in provision of safe water and sanitation coverage especially affected the new arrivals from Sudan. other key needs are in the areas of protection with increasing number of individuals and families seeking training serivces that until recently closed out from this settlement due to funding gaps. There is also major gap accomodation space at the reception centre, as well as no support towards provision of shleters to Person of Special Needs (PSNs) who are unabale to cotruct won houses and latrines. Key institutions including the reception cenre, schools and health facilities too are faced with inadequate toilet facilities, intermitten water supply and challenge of solid waste management. The health care services in Kiryandongo refugee settlement are overwhelmed due to this increasing population pressure; whereby drug stock-outs, limited number if health care workforce, and limited diagnostic capacities is barring the refugees and asylum seekers from accessing proper medical care.

It is feared that the current congestion, poor housing, inadequate WASH infrastructure and the minimal health conditions might lead to major outbreak of communicable diseases, including cholera, typhoid and measles and others. Furthermore, the current overstretched reception capacity including screening, registration and allocation of plots s already resulting in overstays at the reception center that poses increased protection risks. Moreoiver, the inadequate shelter infrastructures for those resettled in the plots of land will expose new arrivals, particulalrly PSNs to adverse weather conditions for the duration of stay that increass their risks to respiratory tract infections and malaria infestations.  

Besides, many of the refugees and asylum seekers might move out to urban centres to seek better living conditions  thus posing risks of family seperations and related protection risks. 

To help mobilse resources to address these gaps, the OPM and UNHCR drafted a Continecy Plan targeting Sudanese refugee influx in Uganda in March 2024 but the response to this appeal is quite slow that leaves many partners very limited response capacities.

field_reports.description:
May 2024 started with serious impact by floods and landslides as was the case in April. In 11 days, 39,185 people (8,011 households) were affected by flood hazard in 14 districts in Uganda as shown in Table 1 below. 3,080 households were displaced. According to the latest Uganda National Meteorological Authority (UNMA) forecast, more rains are expected in the remaining part of May 2024. The widespread impact of floods has overwhelmed the response capacity of URCS and other humanitarian actors. URCS has done 14 responses but the needs are still immense, requiring additional support.

field_reports.epi_notes_since_last_fr: Since January 2024, Uganda has registered outbreaks of measles in 8 districts of Arua city, Kyenjojo, Kasese, Obongi, Yumbe, Hoima, Amuru and Yumbe. A total of 791 measles were detected with 58 laboratory confirmed, 733 epi-linked and 3 deaths. Overall, the regions affected are either bordering the Democratic Republic of Congo or refugee hosting districts.
field_reports.description:
Uganda has registered measles outbreaks in eight districts/cities across the country since January 2024. The Ministry of Health conducted a rapid measles risk assessment which revealed that an estimated 41 districts are at high risk of measles, an additional 73 districts are considered at moderate risk of measles and other vaccine preventable diseases. This is a threat to the current progress Uganda has made to stop measles in the country.
Data from all the measles outbreaks investigated indicates that the outbreaks are due to pockets of unimmunized or under immunized children, which is made further made worse by porous borders, free population movements and sub optimal active surveillance in some regions.

field_reports.epi_notes_since_last_fr: Eight suspects were reported in the last 24 hours, four of which have been confirmed. The outbreak is active in two sub-counties, potentially spreading to other sub-counties. Fifty animal deaths have been confirmed.
field_reports.description: The Health System has been constrained regarding Human resources, supplies, Fleet, and other operational costs. This results from robust surveillance, risk communication, infection prevention and control, Psychosocial support, and coordination mechanisms set up to contain the disease. The community's well-being has been affected due to the disruption in livelihood activities across the response sub-counties. This will be reversed as soon as the outbreak is contained.

field_reports.description:
The fight in the DRC has accelerated and affected the villages Kiwangya, Ruchuru and Bunanga areas. 

Matanda is a transit area situated in the sub-county of Matanda in Kanungu distrist. The centre has the capacity to hold 800 refugees at one time. Matanda transit area was in the recent past host to 51 refugees who had not been transported to the different settlements. However recent increased fighting in DRC saw an increase of population influx. On Sunday 30/10/2022 a total of 140 refugees were registered that included 66 females and 74 males, bringing the total number of 191 people in the transit area.

On Monday 31/10/2022 48 the 51 refugees previously residing at the transit centres were taken to Kyaka. 78 refugees were registered that included 37 Females and 39 Males, making a total of 221 refugees at the transit centre.

On Tuesday 1/11/2022 a total of 53 refugees were registered, making the total number of refugees at the transit centre to be 274

results.name: UGANDA - Ebola Virus Disease Outbreak - 2022
results.summary:
In a statement issued on 20 September 2022, the Ministry of Health, notified a positive case of Ebola virus disease which indicates outbreak of the Sudan strain of Ebola virus disease (EVD) [GE1] [DKM2] in the district of Mubende. Ebola virus, part of the class of filoviridae, has multiple strains, of which the Zaire and Sudan strains are the most common.

On the 15 September 2022, one suspected case-patient of Viral Haemorrhagic Fever (VHF) was identified and isolated in Mubende Regional Referral Hospital (RRH). The suspected case-patient was a 24-year-old male who lived in Ngabano village of Madudu Sub County in Mubende District. Prior to isolation at Mubende RRH, he is reported to have sought care from St. Johns Medical clinic in Katwe cell, Kyatetekera ward in Mubende Municipality on 14th to 15th September 2022 where he was managed for pneumonia before being referred to Mubende RRH for further management.

He presented with high grade fever, convulsions, blood-stained vomitus and diarrhoea, loss of appetite and pain on swallowing. He also presented with chest pain, dry cough, and bleeding in the eyes. While in the isolation unit at Mubende RRH, he developed yellowing of eyes, tea coloured urine and complained of abdominal pain on the 17 September 2022. The clinical team took a sample from the patient having suspected a VHF. The sample was received at the VHF laboratory at Uganda Virus Research Institute (UVRI) on the 18 September 2022, and results released on the 19 September 2022 confirmed Ebola (Sudan strain) infection.

contacts.name: Daniel Mutinda
contacts.title: Delegate, Disaster Management    Juba Cluster Delegation, (South Sudan, Uganda and Tanzania)

field_reports.description:
URCS 04-hour rapid report:

Subcounty: Rukoki

Village: Kasika trading centre,

Parish: Kigoro 1

Subcounty: Rukoki

Estimated HH: 170

Estimated Houses: 20

Estimate population: 1190

Summary:

Missing 7

Injured 7

Dead 15 people

Type of disaster: Mudslide

Narration:

Heavy rains were characterized by heavy surface flow water started around 1.00am these later progressed into a landslide at around 2.00am.

The heavy surface water flow was flowing though the valley and as it went downstream it started covering up the households in its path.

People started making alarm and running away from their HH. Those that were able to run got away and others were buried in their houses by the heavy rains and soils. The survivors later came back to the scene to look in the morning of the aftermath.

Issues:

·         HH destroyed (partially and most completely destroyed)

·         Children whose parents are missing

·         Bodies still buried under the mudslide

·         Estimated 2km stretch of gardens and crops destroyed. This included beans, matooke, cocoa, vanilla

 

12-hour joint rapid assessment report coordination by Kasese DDMC:

Rukoki Sub County on Tuesday September, 2022 experienced high rainfall intensity from Midnight to around 4:00am characterized by windstorms, and heavy surface flow that concentrated in the valley from Kalingatha Village to Kasika trading centre in Kasika Village- Kigoro I Parish covering an approximate length of 2 km before sweeping the households that happened to be along its way before it joined the nearby Kigoro stream. Onsite it was seen that the subject valley is characteristic of interlocking spers that open in the main valley from the ridges that lie side by side that finally opens at Kasika trading centre. It’s believed that the water brought through the numerous interlocking spars on both sides of the valley accumulated to cause a bigger volume of surface flow that first eroded the top one metre deep of the top soil while plucking the available vegetation cover before it poured into and swept all houses and other properties along its way. Other areas like Kabughabugha with similar physical characteristics were equally affected by the mudslide as it has a very long stretch characteristic of of the interlocking spars in the upper catchment

SUMMARY OF THE DISASTER EFFECT

Type of disaster Mudslide

Cause of the disaster Persistent Heavy rains

Rivers/ Stream flooded N/A

Sub counties affected Rukoki

Villages affected 5 Kasika, Mukathi, Kigoro, Kabughabugha,

Kalingatha

Number of Hhs affected 170

Number of People affected 1,190

Number of Hhs in host families 0

Number of people internally displaced 714

Number of IDP camp(s) proposed 1 at Kogere CoU

Number of Hhs in the IDP Camp 101

Number of IDPs in the IDP Camp 700

Number of crop fields affected (acres) 60

Crops/plants affected Coffee, Cocoa, Vanilla, Beans, Bananas,

cassava, Eucalyptus, maize

Livestock affected Goats, Pigs, Sheep,

Poultry affected Chicken and ducks,

Number of schools affected 1,

Name of school(s) affected Kigoro P/s

Number of classrooms affected 0

Number of worship places affected 1 Kogere CoU

Number of houses destroyed 20

Number of health facilities affected 0

Business Retail shops, the main Trading centre at Kasika

20 Houses with a total population of 140 people from the villages 05 villages Kasika, Mukathi, Kigoro, Kabughabugha, Kalingatha were completely destroyed.

Current situation

WATER AND SANITATION

 20 latrines in the villages Kasika, Mukathi, Kigoro, Kabughabugha, Kalingatha were

completely destroyed. There is a likelihood of diarrhea disease including cholera in

these villages if these pits are not reconstructed immediately.

 One water protected spring (Kamusonge) was completely destroyed

 Kigoro stream was heavily contaminated

ROADS AND OTHER INFRASTRUCURE

 Kigoro-Kasika-Buhaghura 9.01 km road was heavily destroyed

 A section of the power line was destroyed with a number of electric poles

LIVELIHOODS, HEALTH, AND NUTRITION

Over 65 acres of crop fields with kasika village, 30 Acrers, Kabughabigha 10 Acres, Mukhathi 5

acres, Kigoro 20 acres, while 5 acres were destroyed in Kalinghatha village. The harvests from

these fields were mainly meant for home consumption and commercial. The Affected communities will most likely experience hunger due to the poor or no harvest.

As indicated in the summary table, the following crops were affected by the disaster; Coffee, Cocoa, Vanilla, Beans, Bananas, cassava, Eucalyptus, maize, and G/nuts.

Retail shops, and the main trading centre (Kasika) in the sub county was destroyed.

IMMEDIATE INTERVENTIONS TAKEN

 Evacuation of the mudflow disaster victims.

 Carry out onsite visits and data collection by the A rapid assessment team instituted by CAO

 Established an IDP camp at Kogere CoU

 Internally displaced households have been encouraged to go Kogere Church of Uganda for hostage as relief support is being mobilized.

 Psychosocial support is ongoing

 A number of risk areas that are not conducive for human settlement have been sighted.

People in risky areas have been encouraged to get to the safer zones.

 Handing bodies to the families for dignified and decent burial after postmortem by the medical officers

 Share of rapid assessment information with stakeholders at local, National and international levels for rapid response

results.name: Uganda : Floods 2022
results.summary:
On 30th July 2022, eastern Uganda received 10 hours of continuous heavy rains in the Elgon region causing floods in the districts of Mbale, Kapchorwa, Bulambuli, Bukedea, Butaleja Sironko and landslides in Bududa.  

 

The flooding led to the loss of 21 lives in Mbale and 3 lives in Kapchorwa districts respectively with an unknown number of livestock lost. Further, the flooding left a trail of destruction to homesteads, schools, government and social institutions, damage to vehicles and displacement of thousands of people from their homes. Those displaced populations are currently in host families within safer zones in the neighbourhood while others are currently living at established temporary internally displaced persons camps in nearby primary schools. Bridges have been cut off and roads filled with debris limiting the delivery of needed humanitarian assistance and effective search and rescue.  Four health centres have been submerged while the remaining ones are not accessible, and people travel long distances to access health care.  

 

Combined with search and rescue, rapid assessments have been conducted revealing the extent of the flooding with some parts of Bududa district facing landslides.   

The weather forecast by the Uganda National Meteorological Authority (UNMA) for the Elgon region for the month of August 2022 has projected enhanced rains for the region with the possibility for the flooding challenges to continue.  

 

In recent years, flood disaster occurrences in Uganda have become more frequent, particularly in the low-lying and built-up urban areas in the Eastern and South-western regions as well as in the areas near major water bodies of Lake Victoria, Lake Kyoga and Lake Albert that were affected by flash-floods due to rising water levels. These flood events are causing more devastating effects. The high concentration of people in large cities is promoting the uncontrolled expansion of construction. Generally, June, July and August are the wettest months in Uganda, and the situation is expected to worsen as the rainy season continues until the end of August 2022.

contacts.name: Daniel Mutinda
contacts.title: Delegate, Disaster Management    Juba Cluster Delegation, (South Sudan, Uganda and Tanzania)

field_reports.description:
Heavy and extended rains started about 8:00pm on 30th July 2022 in Eastern Uganda leading to flooding in the areas of Mbale, Kapchorwa, and Sironko. 2 rivers in Mbale burst their banks and flooding occurred.
The floods have affected houses and crops in gardens. Infrastructure such as roads, bridges and culverts were also destroyed or damaged.
Some vehicles with occupants were washed into drainage channels and several people drowned.

Update as of Monday 01st August 2022:
Mbale
 20 RCATs (Red Cross Actions Teams are first responder volunteers) deployed to support rapid needs assessment
 2 Ambulances deployed to work with Ministry of Health and partners
 Areas most affected: Namabasa, Bugwere Cell, Bungoko subcounty (in 3 villages)
 So far 20 people have been registered dead due to flooding from Nabuyonga river and River Nambale among other areas(Search and rescue is still ongoing)
 52HHs were affected in Bugwere cell
 578HHs were affected in 20 villages in Bunghoko Sub county
 50HHs have been affected from Busamaga, over 25people have relocated to Pencoat PS.
 Bridges in Musoto, Kaguta were washed away
 Mbale Nkonkojeru road was blocked
 Bubyangu registered one death, One person drowned in River Nakhibiso and 267HHs affected.
 Namabasa has so far registered over 350HHs affected

Kapchorwa
10 RCATs deployed to support Rapid Needs assessment
Areas most affected: Kapsida subcounty, chemalim village, Tuyobei Parisi,
No. of people affected: 3 dead, 4 injured referred to Kapchorwa main hospital with 1 referred to Mbale Hospital
1 Ambulance deployed.
 4HHs totally destroyed in Munurya Subcounty.
 6HHs partially destroyed

Sironko district
 20 RCATs deployed to support rapid needs assessment
 Most affected areas: Sironko (Sironko Town Council, Bukise S/C, and villages of Town council village, Busambya, Bumukha, Doko, Nabirete, Dorcus, Bukiyende, Namirende
 No. of people affected: Households 480. No death, or reported injuries

Bulambuli district
- Dwikhonge S/C, Duwadwala Parish: Villages Diwadwala, Busiyango, Buyakha, Bunabalayo, Kori, Sipi, Bumugoya.
 Labongo S/C: Mpumbura parish, Muyende S/C
 No. of people affected: No death or reported injuries. Households 672
In both Bulambuli and Sironko districts
- No deaths, No injured victims, the floods destroyed crops, pit latrines were soaked and collapsed, roads are impassable but the water is slowly drying, water sources were contaminated. Currently 1,152 HHs have been affected from both areas

Bukedea
 Kamutur, Kolir and Aminit sub counties were affected with a total number of 806HHs. 588M and 714F. They were affected by both floods and landslides.
 1 Death was registered from Busano
 35 persons were injured
 People are currently relocating to their relatives and friends places. Some relocated to Busano and Tajar PS but were ask to leave due to the poor conditions at the schools. The buildings are also at a risk of collapsing

Update as of 2nd Aug. 2022
•	The Uganda National Meteorological Authority has predicated of heavy rainfall in the Elgon region and likely to prolong through the month of August 2022.

•	An estimated number of 5,600 people have been displaced, about 150 households submerged and swept downstream. Currently 30 people have sought shelter at Pentecot a private primary school and other living with relatives.  400,000 people have been cut of the National Water grid, sewer lines damaged in all areas along the river banks and reclaimed swampy areas. These events have predisposed the entire population (586,300) of Mbale district and city; 307800(52%) are males and 278500(48%) are females, Children under 5 are 64180. 

•	With limited access to essential health care services for submerged areas, consequences of unsafe water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) are bound to cause a cocktail of diarrheal diseases. Malnutrition is projected to set as many families have lost their source of livelihoods – crops and livestock. The trend of events might spark cases of domestic violence and social rejection/ Imbalance among others. 

More information to be shared after the assessment.

contacts.title: Delegate, Disaster Management    Juba Cluster Delegation, (South Sudan, Uganda and Tanzania)

field_reports.description:
Background 
Karamoja, located in the northeast, is one of the poorest regions in Uganda, with income poverty at 66% (having increased from 61% in 2017) and food poverty at 75% (having increased from 70% in 2017) (UBOS: UNHS 2019/20). The population is mainly rural, with livelihoods based on livestock and crop production, and of recent a growing range of diversified livelihood activities that include mining, stone quarrying and sale of natural resource products, among others. The region continues to have the highest food insecurity and malnutrition levels in Uganda due to factors related to inadequate food access, poor dietary diversity, structural poverty, low value livelihood options, poor hygiene and sanitation, and morbidity. 
The ongoing drought in the Horn of Africa has affected the Karamoja sub-region. High food prices have left many families unable to afford nutritious foods – forcing them to find other ways to cope.  Some families have been forced to consume their seed stocks, leaving nothing for the planting season while others have had to borrow money or reduce expenditure on necessities such as education and health with others forced to sell valuable assets like ox-ploughs as scrap.
Insecurity, cattle rustling, COVID-19 aftershock, rising food prices, climate change and limited resources are some of the factors pushing thousands of Karimojong households into destitution, according to the latest Integrated Food Security Phase Classification (IPC)  analysis released in Kampala on June 8.
It’s the first time in three years that all the nine districts of Karamoja; Abim, Amudat, Kaabong, Karenga, Kotido, Moroto, Nabilatuk, Nakapiripit and Napak are at food crisis level or worse.
The IPC report further predicts that while food insecurity is likely to improve slightly between August 2022 and January 2023, its longer-term impact, acute malnutrition, is likely to stay in the same worrying state.
According to the latest analysis, over 40% of the population (518,000 people) in Karamoja is facing high levels of food insecurity. Last year, when similar analysis was done, the figure was about 30% (361,000 people).
Of the 518,000 people with high levels of food insecurity, 428,000 are experiencing phase three (crisis levels of food insecurity) and 90,000 people are at phase four (emergency levels of food insecurity).
In Moroto District, one of the nine districts that make up Karamoja sub-region of northeastern Uganda, over half of the population goes without any food for an entire day and night for at least three days a month.
Analysts say the situation has been exacerbated by insecurity that has driven people away from their homes and destabilized crop production. Cattle raids have robbed people of animals on which they depended for nutritious food. Delayed and unpredictable rainfall and diseases such as COVID-19 and malaria have further deepened the crisis.
“The situation in Karamoja is an example of how a perfect storm of climate change, conflict, rising food costs, the impact of Covid-19 and limited resources is increasing the number of hungry people,” said Abdirahman Meygag, the WFP Uganda Representative.
Young children and pregnant and breastfeeding women are among the most vulnerable in Karamoja. The IPC acute malnutrition analysis  indicates that 91,600 children and 9,500 pregnant or breastfeeding women are acutely malnourished and in urgent need of treatment.
Around 2.4 % of children in Karamoja are severely malnourished – an increase from 1.9% in 2021. Another 10.7% of children are moderately malnourished, up from 8.8%.
In Kotido, Napak, Nabilatuk and Amudat districts, acute malnutrition is at critical levels while Karenga, Abim and Nakapiripit are on alert. Except for Abim and Karenga districts that have registered a slight improvement, acute malnutrition has worsened in all the other seven districts.
At 4,791, Moroto district has the highest absolute number of children who are severely malnourished. Moroto, Kotido, Kaabong districts account for almost 55 % of children under five years in need of malnutrition treatment in Karamoja sub-region.
With the current situation in Karamoja, there is an increase in the number of households facing widening food consumption gaps and utilizing negative livelihood coping strategies, thus increasing the share of the population that is experiencing Crisis (IPC Phase 3) outcomes.
With URCS being a key National partner in emergency intervention, there is a need to join other partners trying to close the gap among households in the region, through the provision of immediate protective cash relief and later move to rehabilitation and development programming.  

Justification 
Karamoja continues to experience two major challenges: chronic water shortages and chronic food shortages. Other challenges include high poverty levels, low literacy and skill development, poor and inadequate infrastructure, high prevalence of diseases, severe environmental degradation, and new threats to security from armed pastoralists across the border from Kenya and Southern Sudan.
Due to climate extremes, and other weather and climate events leading to chronic water shortages, Karamoja today has the highest prevalence of food insecurity in Uganda (WFP, 2015). Before 2010, the Karamoja sub-region was always dependent on food aid. Despite a number of interventions since then, the food security situation remains a concern.
According to the June-September outlook for Karamoja published by USAID’s Famine Early Warning Systems Network (FEWSNET), the above-average rainfall forecast from April to September is expected to support a timely start to the harvest in July.
The IPC results released are not so different from what has been seen in the last few years. There is also a need to shift focus from responding only to the food insecurity crisis in Karamoja every year after it has already happened but integrating sustainable climate-smart production approaches that address food gaps in the region. 
As per IPC reports, the availability of food and income is expected to further decline as the lean season progresses through July. As such, an increasing number of households are expected to face consumption gaps and Crisis (IPC Phase 3) outcomes, with worst-affected households deteriorating to Emergency (IPC Phase 4). 
Accordingly, the UNICEF report of March –April 2022, it does show a high level of food insecurity deterioration in Karamoja region, and if current conditions continue, 22,740 children in Karamoja are projected to suffer from severe acute malnutrition (SAM) by January 2023, while 68,870 children are projected to suffer from moderate acute malnutrition (MAM).
Based on the above gaps, there is a need for URCS to respond to the climate-induced hunger crisis by saving lives, protecting livelihoods, and promoting the early recovery of the most food-insecure communities in Karamoja region while collaborating with the District Local government structures and WFP and FAO who are the key partners in the region.

contacts.name: Daniel Mutinda
contacts.title: Delegate, Disaster Management    Juba Cluster Delegation, (South Sudan, Uganda and Tanzania)

field_reports.description:
Heavy rains and strong winds in Lokopo Sub-county

Following heavy rainfall accompanied by a strong winds that occurred on 26th and 29th April 2022, classroom block roofs of two primary Schools i.e. Lokopo Primary School in Lokopo TC, Namugit Parish, Lokopo Sub-county, and Kalochonga Community Primary School in Kalochonga Village, Lorikitae Parish – Lokopo Sub-county, were blown off, casting uncertain cloud on the pupils that are due to report for their second term.  
In addition, the floods cut off one road that connects Lokopo Sub County and Matany Town Council through Kayepas - Longalom Parish, making Matany Town School that hosts the only functional Hospital - Matany Hospital inaccessible by any Motorized means of transport except footing.

Heavy rains and strong winds in Kanaura village in Nakichumet Parish

Heavy rains and strong winds affected 32 households in Kanaura village - Nakichumet parish - Matany Sub-county, as 20 houses were blown off, while others brought down, displacing people and leaving them destitute.

field_reports.description:
URCS Bundibugyo Branch reports that there is a refuge influx in Bundibugyo district along Busunga border which is said to be a result of fresh conflict and attack of Nobile communities (in DRC) by armed forces yesterday night (Saturday, 10th April 2022).

Over 1,000 asylum-seekers have crossed through the border from DRC to Uganda and more are expected to come in by the end of today.

A situation report will be shared later.
field_reports.summary: UGA: Population Movement - 2022-04 - Uganda - Western Region: Refugee Influx 04/2022 #2 (2022-04-10)

contacts.name: Daniel Mutinda
contacts.title: Delegate, Disaster Management    Juba Cluster Delegation, (South Sudan, Uganda and Tanzania)

field_reports.description:
Following the increase influx of asylum seekers in Kasese District – South-Western via porous borders of Kiraru and Ndulende in Kanyatsi Parish in Kitholhu Subcounty in Kasese District, the COA called an emergency coordination meeting on Wednesday 6th April 2022. All Development partners/ Implementing partners in and outside the District were invited to attend.  The meeting was chaired by the Deputy RDC. Partners in attendance; URCS, UNHCR, WFP, Save the Children, CAFOMI, OPM, MSF, MTI. 
A Joint assessment was conducted shortly after the meeting to Karambi playground to site where a Reception centre can be set up and identify other humanitarian needs that need to be addressed.

Key issues/gaps/Needs discussed
•	Food
•	Majority of the asylum seekers children and women – therefore vulnerable
•	WASH needs
•	Non Food Items (Tapaulins, Jerricans, Mosquito nets, soap, saucepans, cups, plates, blankets, 
•	Latrine construction
•	Medication since many children seem not to be immunized due to poor health systems in DRC hence fear of measles outbreak
•	UAMs, some children interviewed by local leaders, MSF and Red Cross volunteers said they had no relatives with them, they followed those who were running because their parents had gone to the gardens while others had gone for casual labor. Other tracing needs were also established as people want to reestablish and maintain contact of their families and relatives whom they do not know their whereabouts.
•	Mental illness, people look so stressed and exhausted
•	Sanitary materials for young girls and mothers in reproductive age.
•	Emergency Medical Services – High number of pregnant and lactating mothers but also the long distance covered has made some of them fall sick and need urgent medical attention.
•	Firewood for food preparation 
Threats 
•	It was reported by UPDF that on analysis, most of the asylum seekers are children and women – there was a high suspicion that most able-bodied men could be engaged in rebel activities. Therefore, the security at the boarder need to be tightened and the camps should be shifted from the 2 churches which are a few kilometers away from where the attacks happened in DRC for protection purposes. 
•	UPDF also reported that 100 asylum seekers had been reported in Bwesumbu and Buhuhira Subcounties still in Kasese and these subcounties are bordering Bundibugyo District)
field_reports.summary: UGA: Population Movement - 2022-04 - Uganda - Western Region: Refugee Influx 04/2022

results.name: UGA: Population Movement - 2022-04 - Uganda - Western Region: Refugee Influx 04/2022
results.summary:
Families fleeing violence in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) are arriving in Uganda traumatized and without possessions, in the hope of reaching safety. However, they find themselves in another humanitarian crisis as there is insufficient shelter to house them, and overcrowded centres lack water and sanitation, forcing people to camp out in the open putting their safety and health at risk.

The conflict in the North Kivu and Ituri provinces in the eastern part of the DRC has intensified since late March 2022, triggering the large-scale displacement of refugees into Uganda. Up to 26 May, Uganda had received over 41,018 new arrivals fleeing the violence from DRC.

From 10 June, the IFRC has seen a further increase in people crossing the border due to an escalation in violence in the DRC. Families have been forced to flee with limited or no possessions and can be seen camping on the streets, in schools, markets, and on the open grounds of border towns Bundibugyo and Bunagana. Due to the sudden increase in people crossing, not all have been registered and, hence, the numbers are not at this stage confirmed but it is estimated they could have increased to over 100,000 people, putting a significant strain on host communities.

This rapid and large-scale influx of refugees has put tremendous pressure on the basic social services in the settlements where refugees are hosted, impacting education, food, shelter, health and nutrition centres, and WASH infrastructure.

The refugees are received at several collection points, transit, and reception centres across the country. They are registered and provided with basic protection services and humanitarian assistance pending their relocation to refugee settlements. Besides those registered at the camps, there is a large number of additional refugees still living with host communities in Bundibugyo and Bunagana.

The influx of refugees has created a large gap in terms of shelter. The transit centres are designed to host refugees for a maximum of five days, but the situation has forced longer stays. Refugees have arrived with few belongings and there is an urgent need for emergency shelters and essential household items.

The transit centres and camps are already congested and lack sufficient health, water, and sanitation facilities raising the risk of disease outbreaks if no immediate actions are taken with regard to health, hygiene, and sanitation. Their basic shelter and WASH infrastructure need to be upgraded to comply with the minimum humanitarian standards at the receiving locations. Refugees face numerous protection issues; including cases of sexual and gender-based violence (SGBV), separated families and unaccompanied minors and many more all arising due to the magnitude of the displacement and growing vulnerabilities, and strained basic social services in refugee-hosting communities. The level of trauma is high among the current refugee population and additional psychosocial assistance is needed. Some families have been displaced three or four times, thereby, leading to a continuous cycle of displacement in settlements.

contacts.name: Daniel Mutinda
contacts.title: Delegate, Disaster Management    Juba Cluster Delegation, (South Sudan, Uganda and Tanzania)

field_reports.description:
Kapelebyong district is comprised of one county and as a district it is located in the north eastern part of the country. The district has a total land area of 1,204 square kilometers. The district boards karamoja that is Napak and Kotido and also Abim district. 
The district in the recent weeks experienced the threats from the karamojongs who had brought their cattle to graze in the neighboring sub counties in kapelebyong that is Okungur, Achinga, Kapelebyong and Acowa sub counties. Due to the constant theft of cattle from the communities the communities decided to call for the security meeting with the district representatives band requested the district to send away the karamonjongs who were in the community to go back, as a result the karamojongs then decided to become hostile and decided to come back and attack the communities.
On Tuesday 5th/April/2022 at a round 10:00am the karamojongs decided to become hostile during the morning hours and decided to attack the community chasing the entire community members in the sub counties of Okungur, Achinga, Kapelebyong and Acowa. This left the communities displaced meaning at the time of attack the pupils were at school and parents at home, this left the parents take on their routes and the children were also at school take on their way hence no contact between the children and parents, but the tracing bit is on for uniting this children using the district structures and the nearby radios.

The situation report of the most affected sub counties is as follows,
KAPELEBYONG SUBCOUNTY 
Kapelebyong Sub County is located in the eastern part of the district and has for long been disorganized by the invasion of the Karamojong warriors.
Early this month, the invasion of karamojong warriors affected three parishes of the sub county out of the five (05) namely; Okoboi, Amaseniko and Atiira parishes and those that were not affected included Amemia and Nyada were some people have gone to take refuge.
This has affected the above named parishes well-being of the population above all access to education. The displacement of the communities left 2,518 households displaced with the total population of 13, 308 persons living miserable lifestyle in Kapelebyong sub county.       


OKUNGUR SUB COUNTY
Okungur Sub County as per the ranking is the most affected community which is bordering Napak and Abim districts which is the entry route for the karamonjongs into the community.
The affected parishes here are Arabet with the villages of Okungur, Obulin being the worst affected with people in camps and churches. Here by a round 3:00pm they don’t expect the community members to be moving out of the camp because that’s the time the karamonjongs start moving.
This has affected the above named parish well-being of the population above all access to education. The displacement of the communities left 632 households displaced with the total population of 5,206 persons living miserable lifestyle in Okungur Sub County.               


ACHINGA SUB COUNTY
Similarly like other sub counties Achinga is also at the board with a large swamp were these karamonjongs used to bring their cattle to provide water for their cattle, as a result the karamonjongs have decided to displace all the members in Achinga and they have taken control of the sub county with the advantage of the water source that is the swamp. The entire community here is camping in primary schools, community stores and churches plus relatives.
This has affected the above named parishes well-being of the population above all access to education. The displacement of the communities left 3,098 households displaced with the total population of 13,000 persons.           


ACOWA SUB COUNTY                                                      
 Acowa like other sub counties is an entry point at the board with a large swamp were these karamonjongs used to bring their cattle to provide water for their cattle, as a result the karamonjongs have decided to displace all the members in Achinga and they have taken control of the sub county with the advantage of the water source that is the swamp. The entire community here is camping in primary schools, community stores and churches plus relatives.
This has affected the above named parishes well-being of the population above all access to education. The displacement of the communities left 3,098 households displaced with the total population of 13,000 persons.

field_reports.description:
•	Total population transported and received at the holding area yesterday 8th April 2022 was 619 individuals and this brings to 9,406 individuals received since 28 March 2022. Out of 9,406 individuals 8,014 (4,150 HH) were manually registered through level one as of 8 April 2022. Today around 5 buses were received at the transit centre after OPM directed that all refugees at Bunagana should be brought to the Transit Centre. 

•	Fighting continued to be reported in most parts of the DRC. The refugees continued to flee crossing the border at Bunagana and other locations in areas surrounding the boarder. According to the updates received from the team that went to Bunagana boarder where the Red Cross was part fighting has spread to other places like Cyanzu, Kinyamahura, Runyoni and some parts of Kiwanja. Agencies have therefore been agued to mobilise for more resources in terms of funding and human resource.

field_reports.summary: UGA: Population Movement - 2022-04 - Uganda - Western Region: Refugee Influx 03/2022 #3 (2022-04-06)

field_reports.description:
Situation Update – 29/03/2022

The security situation in DRC has continued to remain unpredictable, fighting has continued today by rolling out into close boarders of Bunagana and Kibaya in DRC forcing new and fresh influx crossing into Kisoro – Uganda. Because of exchange of fire closer to Uganda boarder (Bunagana), the Ugandan army forces has been beefed up at Bunagana that has compelled the Ugandan boarder to be temporary closed by authorities, by close of business today there was no cross boarder movement allowed on either sides for non-refugees. People and business at Bunagana center has been advised to temporarily close in anticipation of any possible attack also giving room for UPDF to remain in full patrol and control. The current population as earlier reported has slightly increased after the fresh fighting in Kibaya and Bunagana communities making the numbers to continue raising up to an estimate of from 5000 – 6500, though the majority are still at the boarder collection center due to
•	Some are still assessing the security situation across the country of origin for the possibility of going back.
•	Inadequate transport provided by UNHCR to relocate them to the transit center.
•	Others fear to be relocated to the permanent settlement since returnees are telling them harsh life.
•	There is inadequate knowledge about relocation to Nyakabande.

As previously reported, the asylum seekers are currently camped at the old transit center, about 600- 700 asylum seekers are currently at this center and out of this between 400 – 450 are women and children, according to some few women whom we managed to talk to it was discovered that the head of families have been left behind and others at Bunagana as they propose to sneak back and check on their properties and gardens.

Though all new arrivals that arrived yesterday and those of today have continued to camp at Bunagana primary school and playground have been advised OPM and district authorities to vacant the school and play ground and be relocated to Nyakabande transit center but have continued persistently refuse to move to the transit center despite the RDCs order. By end of today, majority asylum seekers were still occupying the playground, school premises and surrounding communities of Bunagana trading center. Due to the closure of the main entry point of Bunagana, people are now using other numerous porous entry points of Kibaya where an average of 300 – 400 have been seen through Kibaya entry point alone with lots of livestock.

field_reports.description:
Following continued heavy rains in some parts of Apac especially in Apac and Apoi sub counties in Apac district, more storms and strong winds have continued to cause destruction of property (houses and household items, displacement of people, death of animals, destruction of crops and food stocks and other valuable infrastructure like public institutions. 
On 27th March 2022 at around 5 pm in a three-hour heavy down pour characterized with storms, and strong winds was experienced in Apac district and affected mostly Apac and Apoi sub counties.  The storms and heavy winds caused destruction of property (houses and other household items) causing the blowing of roofs, breakages or falling of house walls, latrines and destruction of gardens (Cassava, mangoes, banana, other fruits and crops). Apac Sub Country is most affected especially in Atana, Ayom Jeri, Abaler and Ayegero villages and Apoi Central, Apalamiio in Apoi/Akokoro Sub County Apac District. 
We didn’t receive any report of missing persons though there were reports of 2 causalities undergoing treatment. There are no cases of deaths reported. The Red Cross have responded thorough conducting assessments in partnership with the local leaders of the affected communities. 
Assessment
The Branch manager with support of the local leaders and three volunteers from Apac Branch supported in conducting the assessment in the affected areas. The assessment conducted was based on the extent of the damage. However, there is need for a more detailed assessment to ascertain activities for supporting the affected communities in other areas that have not been covered by the rapid assessment.
Extent of damage.
Three sub counties (Apac, Apoi, and Akokoro) have been affected and this rapid assessment that was made in the only 03 parishes that are mostly affected. 


Extent of damage on social services and the shelter.
Schools Affected	Health Facilities affected	Water facilities affected	Partially damaged Houses	Houses affected completely	Households Displaced
3	1	6	55	59	53

Households with affected shelter
Roof Blown off/destroyed	Wall destroyed
55	32

Households totally whose household items were destroyed
Bedding destroyed	Household items destroyed	Food Stocks destroyed	Other items destroyed and gardens
59	101	59	138


Destruction of crops estimates in Acreage 
Cassava	Mangoes	Banana	Fruit trees	Other Crops
163.5	143	70	77	97

There were a total of 7 occupants that were hurt during the disaster. These victims were from various households and they are undergoing medical care. 

Current situation: 
Some of the affected families are trying to do minor repairs depending on the level of damage done however there are others that are still totally stuck. Amidst all this, some rains have continued and it is expected that more harm may occur in the near future affecting the same or other areas or the same location. People have been rendered to stay in damaged shelters without food stocks, their gardens and some households their items destroyed. 


The LCV vice chairperson Apac district has so far visited the community. This was on the same the Uganda Red Cross Apac team was conducting the assessment. He was also to jointly visit some households together with with the Red Cross team to assess the situation and provide some undisclosed monetary support to extremely affected households.  The district is yet to contact Office of the Prime Minister of the same. The DDMC have not yet been to the ground by the time this assessment was conducted. 
Stakeholders on ground. 
During the assessment a number of stakeholders were on ground:
•	Red Cross (Apac-Apac) 
•	District Local government officials 
•	The local media 
•	Local community (Local Council leadership). 


Sanitation and water
Some Latrines have been destroyed and washed away in all the affected communities. The water sources have not been affected though. Households ought to put in place some sanitation facilities such us drying racks, rubbish pits, hand washing facilities etc.
Public Infrastructure
Roads are passable and affected areas are accessible, water sources aren’t affected.  
Two schools and one church were affected where the roofs and walls were either blown off or walls broken or both, they are as detailed below: 


Shelter:
Fifty-five (55) Households have been affected where roofing for their shelters has been blown off and thirty-two (32) households’ walls of their shelters have been damaged. Presently the above households lack appropriate shelter and have sought assistance from the neighborhood in situations where they are accommodative.  


Food:
59 households have lost their food stocks that was at home and 138 households have lost their gardens and other items.


Threats for further damage:
•	Rain season has just started and is likely to continue
•	Outbreak of diseases like Cholera and dysentery may come as a result of poor sanitation.
•	The pupils in some of the schools which have been completely destroyed are studying under trees and they risk being affects during the onset of more rains.

field_reports.description:
Following the heavy rains that covered the Elgon on the 24th February, 2022, we received an alert from the community on an occurrence of heavy rains that had winds in the area blowing off the roofs of houses and schools in Mbale City, Northern city Division in Namabasa ward. The disaster happened within three villages of Namabasa IV, Namabasa 3A and Namabasa 3 Central with a total population of 461 people affected. We activated our Community Volunteers to conduct a rapid assessment together with the Local Council leadership.
The disaster occurred on Thursday of 24th February, 2022 around 4:00pm in the evening causing destruction of houses, schools, crops and blowing off roofs due to heavy rains thus affecting the community members. This left some people homeless with the only option of running to the neighborhood, friends and relatives for shelter. Meanwhile the affected houses are scattered from the three cells.

         As a result of the heavy rains the following were affected.
         66 houses were cracked and roofs blown off and 25 houses completely destroyed with
         a total population of 461 people.
    12 pit latrines down and others not in good condition and 27 at risk with walls         cracked 
At least three people were injured while most household and their properties were destroyed and taken away by the running water.
A total number of 91 Households have been affected with a population of about 461 people displaced. 

Health Risks
	Due to inadequacy of proper hygiene facilities for human waste disposal, there is a likelihood of water born/diarrheal related disease out-breaks like cholera, dysentery, diarrhea, typhoid and bilharzias which already affects the people.
	High expectation of malaria due to water logged areas.
	There is a likelihood of diseases outbreak as most of the houses are water logged and the pit latrines destroyed.


Food
Its only banana plantations and Cassava stems that were among the items destroyed.

Infrastructure, shelter 
The destroyed houses were mainly temporal and semi-permanent. There is a big worry that incase of any other rains more could be destroyed since there has been too much deforestation in the area.

Accessibility
Some areas in the affected communities are accessible after, though some iron sheets are still hanging on electric wires along some roads making it a threat in case of more rains come.

field_reports.description:
Due to the continuous rains in the Mount Elgon region in the Eastern part of Uganda, cracks have been observed in Bududa subcounty (Bukhibino parish) and Mabono subcounty (Nametsi parish). A previous rapid assessment on 24 October 2021 showed that 162 households (1,051 people - 448 males and 567 females) were affected by landslides in the same areas. This was after relief distribution in Bududa on 21st October 2021 (03 days before). The URCS field monitoring teams have done surveillance and note that an estimated 150 households (900 people) in Bududa subcounty and 240 households (1,440 people) are at high risk and are likely to be affected by landslides anytime.
Risk awareness is ongoing for people in dangerous areas to evacuate to safer areas.

field_reports.description:
Uganda Red Cross has today responded and supported 17 causalities who were injured in the bomb explosions in Kampala. These happened mid-morning at three points/ locations (1. Just outside the Kampala Central Police Station, 2. about 100 metres away from the first, just along Kampala road, outside Kooki Towers/ building, 3. just outside IPS building that houses several offices including Absa bank and the Inspectorate of Government, along Parliament Avenue less than 100 metres from the entrance of Parliament of Uganda).
For the 1st and second, a suicide bomber wearing a jacket and carrying a backpack is seen moving towards the explosion point and then an explosion occurs. For the 3rd, two persons on a motorcycle speed towards the explosion point and then the explosion occurs. These were seen on Police surveillance CCTV camera footages released by the Uganda Police during a press briefing. 
Other responders such as the Police have also handled other cases and numbers are likely to change.
URCS Response:
17 cases were handed by the Red Cross emergency response team. 12 were critical and referred to Mulago National Referral Hospital
5 received on scene care and were discharged 
Ambulances deployed - 3
First responders and Emergency Medical technicians – 50
Response in coordination with Police, Ministry of Health, and KCCA.
One ambulance deployed at Nansana where another bomb scare has been reported at 12:40PM
More Updates will be shared later.

field_reports.description:
According to UNHCR Representative to Uganda11,000 new arrivals from the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) have entered Uganda since Sunday 7th November night, fleeing fighting between militia groups and DRC armed forces in North Kivu’s Rutshuru Territory. 
Some 8,000 refugees crossed at Bunagana and another 3,000 at Kibaya, in Kisoro district – some 500 km southwest of Uganda’s capital Kampala. The refugees are fleeing ongoing fighting in the villages of Binja, Kinyarugwe and Chanzu and fear of further escalation. Many arrived with bags packed with cooking utensils, sleeping mats and clothing as well as livestock, in anticipation of a long stay in Uganda. The vast majority of arrivals are women and children. 
Upon arrival at Nyakabande, the refugees are screened for COVID-19, registered and provided with basic assistance, including communal shelters, food, water and non-food items. A monitoring and referral system is in place to identify and fast track cases in need of emergency assistance. Several partners have joined efforts to respond to this new emergency, including Care and Assistance for Forced Migrants, Medical Teams International, Save the Children, IFRC in country staff, UNHCR, Netherlands Red Cross in country, the Uganda Red Cross and the World Food Programme.
While the borders remain officially closed for refugees due to COVID-19 restrictions, Uganda has once again applied an exception and granted safe passage to people seeking safety and who may be in need of international protection and life-saving assistance. 
As the influx continues, there is concern that local capacities and services may be soon overwhelmed and needs urgent resources to address the needs of the new arrivals.

field_reports.summary: Uganda - Eastern Region: Hailstorm 10/2021

results.name: Uganda - Eastern Region: Hailstorm 10/2021

field_reports.description:
Landslide occurrence in Nakhatore Village, Bunatsushi Parish, Bulucheke Subcounty, Bududa District; It occurred on 14th Oct 2021 at around 5:50am following heavy downpour that lasted over 08 hours from the previous day. It was triggered by the heavy downpour that soaked the ground resulting into movement of soil mass down the hill.
The impact was majorly felt on food and cash crops such as beans, banana plantations and coffee where about 15 acres were swept off by downward movement of soil debris and boulders. 
The total number of affected households so far are 33 with a population of 214 people (98 males and 116 females). 
The most high risk Villages where the cracks are visible include; Bunantsushi Main and Buweli in Bunantushi Parish, Natotowa and Makunda in Bumayemba parish, Luwobe, Napokolo and Lukhuna in Bumasata Parish. The estimated population at risk stands at about 2,100 people with over 300 households from the earlier cited risky villages.
It is important to note that the rains are still pouring and many households are continuously being affected. A detailed assessment is planned to ascertain actual numbers for this landslide and multiple others that are being reporting in the district and region considering the very hilly terrain with steep slopes and the loamy soils.

field_reports.description:
According to the Uganda Red Cross Society Bundibugyo branch, people started fleeing from the inter-ethnic violence that struck the Ituri province in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) on 05th April 2021. Many of the displaced fled to Uganda through major border crossings and porous entry points across Bundibugyo and Ntoroko districts. The immigrants are not registered nor screened for COVID-19, Ebola or any epidemic-prone diseases. Bundibugyo district opened opened the Bubukwanga Refugee Transit Centre (BTC) to accommodate some of the immigrants currently 974 and new entrants have since then continued to flow in.
There is urgent need for face masks, clean water, bedding material, clothes, food, screening, medical assistance for the sick, Pyscho-Social Support, health training and shelter.
field_reports.summary: Uganda - Western Region: Refugee Influx 06/2021

results.name: Uganda - Western Region: Refugee Influx 06/2021

field_reports.description:
A surge in armed and inter-communal violence in areas of Mbogha & Kyabohe in Ituri province the Eastern part of Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) has been reported since the start of April, 2021.	Numerous grave violations including cases of children recruitment into armed groups, killings and maiming of locals (civilians), sexual violence and attacks on schools, hospitals and other social facilities in Ituri province in DRC has again driven over 1,200 Congolese to flee as asylum seekers through Ntoroko and Bundibugyo districts in Western Uganda. 
The arriving refugees were first temporarily accommodated by well wishers and immediate family members in Ntoroko & Bundibugyo districts due to current border restrictions on new refugee entries, and close of reception  centres due to Covid-19 safety protocols in the country. In Bundibugyo district, the refugees first settled in sub-counties of Ntandi, Burondo, Bubukwanga, Ntotoro and Ngamba whereas in Ntoroko they resided majorly in Kanara Sub-county and Kanara Town council, until mid June when they were al transferred to Bubukwangwa reception centre in Bundibugyo district.  
Others are reported to use border entry points and porous entry points and henceforth settling in the population which causes further Covid19 spread worries.  
The rapidly increasing arrival rates, with high levels of unmet needs, where some asylum seekers arrive when injured, exhausted, malnourished and psychologically traumatised; coupled with the high risk from the current upsurge of COVID-19 pandemic in the country places places them in such a precarious status.   Many families report about missing children with some unaccompanied minors, elderly and pregnant women too recorded among the displaced persons. 
As an appraisal of the currently deteriorating situation inside the DRC, the district contingency plan has estimated a planning figure of up-to 5,000 asylum seekers expected to be received and settled at Bubukwangwa reception centre.
field_reports.summary: DRC Refugee Influx in Bundibugyo district, Uganda

results.name: DRC Refugee Influx in Bundibugyo district, Uganda

field_reports.description:
On 27/12/2020, supporters of the National Unity Platform (NUP) Presidential candidate clashed with security officers at Kyabakuza in Masaka district after their convoy was blocked by Police. In this incident, 03 journalists sustained serious injuries and were immediately transported to Masaka Regional Referral Hospital where they were stabilized and later referred to Rubaga Hospital in Kampala, while many other civilians that sustained minor injuries, including intoxication from tear gas , shock and lacerations where either treated on site or referred to Masaka Regional Referral Hospital.
On a separate incident a male adult was reportedly knocked on the same day as the NUP convoy drove one of the injured journalists  from Masaka to Kampala for further medical attention. This casualty later passed-on at Rubaga Hospital, Kampala. This too attracted a crowd at the hospital who were later dispersed through teargas.
On Monday 28.12.2020, the NUP team participated in burial ceremony of the deceased at Kilowooza village in Masaka district, which generally went peacefully with no major incident. 
On the same day, another Presidential candidate got engaged with Security in the Eastern district of Bugiri where he sustained eye injuries from an alleged pepper spray.    
These events follow a similar incident experienced on 18th and 19th  November 2020 in Kampala and other major cities where sections of the public rioted in protest to incidences that led to arrest of 2 presidential candidates, which eventually led to death of over 50 people with scores injured.  
As the country is preparing for general elections to be held on 14th January 2021, this kind of situation might evolve with more serious consequences if emergency response teams are not well prepared to intervene.
field_reports.summary: Uganda - Civil unrest

results.name: Uganda - Civil unrest

field_reports.description:
Since the start of political campaign activities in preparation for the 7th General Elections in Uganda in November 2020, the process to canvas votes has officially closed on Tuesday 12th January 2021 as the country now gets ready to go to the polls for Presidential and Parliamentary positions on Thursday 14th January 2021.  Despite the previous unrest experienced on 17th and 18th November 2020 in Kampala and other cities; in addition to several episodes of localized clashes between campaigning parties and security forces during the campaign periods, the general security situation in the country has been calm and peaceful in the recent days but tense amidst increased security deployment in and around the capital Kampala and across major cities/towns in the country. Since Tuesday 12th January 2021, there is a general interruption in public access to major social media platforms and internet connectivity throughout the country though cell phone coverage still remains accessible.  
Uganda Police Force announced that they have mapped out 39 districts as potential hotspots for violence and are undertaking surveillance and counter measures to prevent potential civil unrests in those areas.
field_reports.summary: Uganda Elections-related violence

results.name: Uganda Elections-related violence

field_reports.description:
Due to heavy rains that are currently experienced in many parts of Uganda, a fresh episode of landslide event occurred in Busano Sub County, in Mbale District on 7th September 2020 at around 23:30 hrs. This followed prolonged rainfall which started at 12:00hrs on 6th September 2020, continuing for over ten hours consecutively thus triggered flooding from Washiende hills downstream. This directly affected 130 households with a population of 868 individuals in five villages whose houses, toilets, domestic animals (6 cows & 10 goats) and food crops were destroyed. One death of a 40-year male was registered, with no missing persons recorded. The floods and landslide event displaced 81 households (405 persons) who are currently camped at Buwangwa CoU Primary school.
Access to the affected communities is currently limited due to the road network which has been destroyed by the landslides.
Since common water sources and sanitation infrastructures have been affected, there is a likelihood of an outbreak of waterborne diseases such as cholera, dysentery and typhoid as affected households lack safe water and facilities for safe disposal of human wastes.
In the long run, affected households might suffer food shortage with resultant effects of malnutrition since most of the households have lost food and cash crops like Onions, Coffee, Matooke and beans as well as animals (cows & goats). 
The situation might evolve to become worst in the coming weeks as weather forecast (SOND 2020) from Uganda National Meteorological Authority (UNMA) indicates that several places in Uganda are most likely to receive prolonged rainfall during the months of September and part of October 2020.
field_reports.summary: Landslides in Mbale and Bundibugyo, Uganda

results.name: Landslides in Mbale and Bundibugyo, Uganda
